job_title: Registered Nurse in La Grange, IL
pros: Flexible schedule, because there is no other staff, you can pick whenever you want to work.
cons: Long term employee writing. This place is NOT what it used to be. Poor pay. What you get walking in the door you can expect to stay at for a long time. Minimal raises that don't cover the cost of living. If you get ill or injured on the job good luck trying to get any compensation without a fight. Management will not support you. Management also is good at hiring staff. They have to be since the turnover rate is so high. Also, you should be willing to compromise your ethics and morals because you will be asked to do things that fly in the face of common sense and you know are not good for patient care. However, they do make the numbers for the hospital " look good" on paper. Also expect to never have a good day at work. The second the census drops you will be sent home. Because you will be working with mostly contract nurses, YOU will be the one sent home, as the contract nurses CAN'T be sent home. Don't expect a flex up in staffing when its busy. The plan for this place when its busy is..... They have NO plan. Take your shiny sign on bonus if you get a job here, but you have been warned.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Hoffman Estates, IL
pros:
Pay for PRN PCT was decent
Hospital experience
cons:
Unwelcoming staff
Management states they are doing "safe staffing" but 1 PCT to 18 patients in acute care is not safe for the PCT or the patients. They're just pinching pennies.
Equipment falling apart, held together with tape
Lots of talking behind others' backs
Not a welcoming atmosphere- I know I mentioned this twice. That's how bad it was. This was the most toxic environment I was ever in.
They keep saying that it's everyone's responsibility to answer call lights but nurses will sit there and ignore call lights even when the PCT is already running around changing people, toileting, taking accuchecks, vital signs...there's no help amongst interdisciplinary teams.
Handled COVID during peak (before vaccines) poorly:
During peak COVID, the director sent out a mass e-mail to everyone on our floor basically telling us that our concerns were invalid and to stop complaining and deal with it.
During peak COVID, housekeeping and dietary would not enter COVID+ rooms so the rooms were always filthy with trash overflowing and sharps bins overflowing.
Did not offer COVID testing
If you got COVID from work, you were financially responsible to seek treatment
When a COVID+ patient was discharged, housekeeping would spend maybe 10 minutes "cleaning" out the room for the next patient. There is no way they disinfected all the surfaces.

Zero support from leadership including charge nurses, manager, director

job_title: Behavioral Health Counselor in Hoffman Estates, IL
pros: Worked inpatient unit at Alexian Brothers Behavioral Health Hospital as a counselor. Good experience for learning how to deal with acute patients, crisis management, and restraining patients that are a danger to themselves or others. Decent pay, good role at beginning of career, but just as a stepping stone. I have heard that this hospital is one of the better ones though in terms of patient aggressiveness and patients being savage. Inpatient is quite a different beast compared to outpatient/IOP/PHP settings.
cons:
Poor, immature leadership. Always short staffed. Burn out concerns from employees is blamed on the employee, and told to 'just deal with it, because everyone is burned out'. 
Big corporation, solely focused on burn and churn type model to maximize revenue at the expense of patient care and staff safety. Only good for experience with hospital inpatient acute population. If you have a license (LPC/LCPC, MSW/LCSW) , go elsewhere. Education/credentials and clinical experience are not valued here. What is valued is being a physically big person, able to physically fight/square up with aggressive patients, and don't mind feeling unsafe when you are threatened by aggressive patients. Management just focuses on getting as many patients admitted as possible regardless of the conditions that staff have to deal with once the pt's are admitted and insurance dollars get flowing (e.g. approving/admitting a patient that is too acute for the current conditions of an already acute milieu that is clearly too short staffed to deal with it). Poor leadership is ruining the value of the treatment and reputation of Alexian Brothers inpatient hospital.

job_title: Special Education Teacher in Glendale Heights, IL
pros: As a special ed teacher at GlenOaks, you work with kind, compassionate and experienced professionals as a member of a team that is looking out for what is best for each student and how to best support each other as staff members. The level of insight into the therapeutic educational process continues to impress me along with the commitment for ongoing education and improvement. Coworkers are more than coworkers, just as the students are more than simply students. For any special ed teachers wondering if it is a good idea to work with students with emotional disabilities (given the data on high burnout for ED teachers), I would recommend taking a second look at GlenOaks. As a therapeutic school, GlenOaks administrators and staff know first-hand the daily challenges you face as a teacher and provide the help, advice and support you need to work successfully in an ED program. Everyone at the school is focused on the same needs and issues so you are not in the position of trying to explain what you or your students need to an administrator or other teachers who cannot really understand because their daily work lives are so different.
cons: For some teachers, it might be frustrating to realize that their academic subjects are secondary to the emotional and behavioral progress the students need to make.

Since coming together with Presence Health the turnover rate has gone up tremendously.   Don't believe anything management tells you - our dept. was told that we were being outsourced to NTT Data but our jobs would be safe.  NOT TRUE. This was only so they could bring in low cost labor to replace the many senior higher paid techs.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in Hoffman Estates, IL
pros: The people I worked with, for the most part, were absolutely amazing. I made lifelong friends.
cons: St. Alexius was bought by Amita Health and their main goal is saving money by cutting staff directly involved in patient care while maintaining a full array of people who work in the sidelines doing various tasks which do not pertain to patient care. They decided to operate with skeleton crews (of RNs, PCTs) causing massive burnout and frustration amongst the staff. Many seasoned nurses have left SAMC to pursue positions at local area hospitals. Now, the hospital seems to be staffed by a lot of new graduate nurses. While we all were there at some point, at least we had some seasoned nurses to watch over us and fall back on. Patients are my favorite, I loved helping with care of each and every one, even the ones I lost.

The resources available for the patients was quite impressive (in-house dietician, oncology RN's that work 1:1 with physicians for clinical trials, coffee, juice, water,  vending machine, comfortable infusion chairs, warm blankets. Clean facility.
cons:
Management is an incredible joke, I had this situation happen below and my manager LITERALLY stared at me like I had 10 eyeballs. I don't care if you have 40 years as an RN, if you look at me and tell me, "So what am I supposed to do about it?" You need to pack up and retire. Jesus. 

I had a physician scream at me in the hallway in front of patient rooms because at least 10 of his patients re-scheduled. He is habitually 2 hours late for clinic. He doesn't understand (or maybe doesn't care) that some of his patients are critically ill and have made a lot of sacrifices to be at their appointment AND on time. He is very condescending, unprofessional, treats the staff like we are incompetent, yelling is actually a pretty common thing for him. You're lucky if you can get him in his office where you can at least shut the door to make sure no patients can hear him.  

"HR" which consists of 1 person in the office and unofficially the office "administrator"  is very biased, choses sides and almost encourages staff gossip, arguments and unnecessary drama because she does NOTHING about it. I can't even begin to describe the amount of inappropriate things that they say about patients, the physicians and management. I don't know how they have time to sit there and talk, I was so busy I barely had time to use the bathroom and was always staying after hours to finish up clinic.
